Research Paper Facile synthesis of efficient and selective Ti-containing mesoporous silica catalysts for toluene oxidation Sreenivasulu Peta a b c Tao Zhang b Viktor Dubovoy a Katherine Koh a Maocong Hu d Xianqin Wang d Tewodros Asefa a b c ⁎ a Department of Chemistryand Chemical Biology, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, 610 Taylor Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey 610 Taylor Road Piscataway NJ 08854 USA b Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, 98 Brett Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey 98 Brett Road Piscataway NJ 08854 USA c Institute for Advanced Materials, Devices and Nanotechnology, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, 607 Taylor Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA Institute for Advanced Materials, Devices and Nanotechnology Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey 607 Taylor Road Piscataway NJ 08854 USA d Department of Chemical, Biological and Pharmaceutical Engineering, New Jersey Institute of Technology, University Heights, Newark, NJ 07102, USA Department of Chemical, Biological and Pharmaceutical Engineering New Jersey Institute of Technology University Heights Newark NJ 07102 USA ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, 610 Taylor Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA. Graphical abstract We report a novel, facile, physical mixing synthetic method that leads to titanium silicate and copper titanium silicate materials or highly effective solid acid catalysts for toluene oxidation reaction. The synthesis involves simple physical mixing of tetraethyl orthosilicate and various titanium alkoxide (and also copper(II) chloride), and then calcination of the products. The effects of the types of precursors on the catalytic activity of the resulting materials are investigated. Notably, titanium(IV) n-butoxide, whose hydrolysis rate is close to that of tetraethyl orthosilicate, yields a material that exhibits strong acidic properties and excellent catalytic activity for toluene oxidation with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as oxidant, giving 98% conversion of toluene and ca. 100% selectivity to benzaldehyde product. The work demonstrates not only simplicity in terms of synthesis of the materials but also unprecedented solid-acid catalytic activity for titanium silicate materials, the catalytic properties of which can be easily tailored by varying the types of precursors. It is also noteworthy that the materials give among the best catalytic performance (in terms of both conversion and product selectivity) under mild reaction conditions that has been reported for toluene oxidation with H2O2 as oxidant for heterogeneous catalysts. Keywords Titanosilicate Copper titanosilicate Toluene oxidation Benzaldehyde Alkane oxidation 1 Introduction Since their discovery in the early 1980’s, various types of Ti-containing silicates or zeolites have been synthesized and their catalytic activities for various reactions have been intensively investigated. These materials have received significant attention in catalysis, because they exhibit unique and versatile catalytic activity toward various reactions including oxidation of alkanes [1], alkenes [2], aromatics [3,4], and alcohols [5]. In particular, the Ti-containing silicate material TS-1, which has isomorphically substituted Ti(IV) moieties within silicate or zeolite materials and which is often prepared via hydrothermal reaction, is of great interest due to its ability to oxidize various organic compounds in the presence of environment friendly oxidants such as aqueous H2O2 [6]. Although TS-1 generally possesses a high surface area, its microporous structure and small pores/cavities can exclude large reactants from reaching the internal catalytic sites [7]. Ti-containing materials with large pores are often synthesized by surface grafting synthetic method especially using SBA-15 mesoporous silica, which has large pore sizes and relatively thick pore walls. While the grafting method allows catalytically-active titanium sites to be introduced into the pore walls of SBA-15 as well as other related mesoporous silica materials, the process unfortunately still reduces the pore size, pore volume and surface area of the materials and compromises their overall catalytic properties [8,9]. In order to overcome this problem, co-condensation synthesis involving the hydrolysis and self-assembly of titania and silica precursors in the presence of surfactant templates to yield porous Ti–O–Si frameworks, has been considered. However, this method too has some drawbacks since the large difference in precursor hydrolysis rates of the two different types of precursors often leads to phase-segregated products [10,11]. For example, the typical titania precursors, titanium(IV) isopropoxide and titanium(IV) chloride, and the typical silica precursors, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and sodium silicate, which are often used for co-condensation synthesis of silica-titania materials, have different hydrolysis rates [12–14]. As a result, attempted co-condensation synthesis of nanoporous silica-titania from them often leads to physically isolated (porous) TiO2 and (porous) SiO2 materials without much of the desired extended Ti–O–Si networks [15–17]. To overcome this problem, some researchers have applied controlled self-assembly synthetic methods involving the silica and titania precursors along with block co-polymers such as Pluronic P123 in solutions under controlled pH and in the presence of chloride ions [18,19]. Under such reaction conditions, the hydrolysis of TEOS is accelerated, matching those of titania’s precursors. Other researchers have employed titania precursors pre-chelated with agents such as acetylacetone, hydrogen peroxide or acetylacetone in order to slow down the hydrolysis of the titania precursors and to make their hydrolysis rates match with that of TEOS [20]. However, these methods involve multiple synthetic steps, costly solvents, and compounds that are detrimental to the environment. Thus, facile synthetic methods that can lead to TS-1 type materials with large pores and robust/extensive Ti–O–Si networks are still desirable. Among the reactions that titanium silicates type materials are known to catalyze, oxidation is a very notable and useful one in chemical industries as it enables the synthesis of a variety of specialty chemicals and intermediates [21,22]. Most of the starting materials commercially used in oxidation reactions are, however, not abundantly available. This issue can be partly addressed by using alkanes, which are available in large abundance and are suitable as chemical feedstocks, if the right catalysts that can oxidize them to various value-added oxygenated products are developed. However, the oxidation or functionalization of the relatively unreactive sp3-hybridized CH bonds of hydrocarbons to oxygenated moieties, especially under mild conditions, remains a major challenge to this day [23,24]. In addition, the partial oxidation of toluene via CH bond activation, where the substrate is prevented from undergoing deep oxidation to benzoic acid, CO2, etc. can be tricky. Toluene is a methyl-substituted benzene or aromatic hydrocarbon, which is widely used industrial feedstock. By subjecting the CH bonds in its methyl substituent to oxidation, various value-added products such as benzaldehyde, benzyl alcohol, benzoic acid, etc. can be produced [25]. Among the products of toluene oxidation, benzaldehyde is particularly useful for the synthesis of various solvents, dyes, perfumes, flavours, plasticizers, flame-retardants, preservatives, pharmaceuticals, etc. [26]. There are some reports on gas phase oxidation of toluene using O2 as oxidant, the reactions involve harsh conditions and are poorly selective to specific products [27,28]. Conventional liquid phase toluene oxidation processes developed by Dow, Snia-Viscosa and Rhodia, which are often carried out with homogeneous metal salt catalysts and oxygen-based oxidants, generate toxic halogenated ionic species and acidic byproducts [29]. Other oxidants such as O2, H2O2 and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) have also been tried for oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde, but in many cases they give the desired product benzaldehyde only in low yields. For toluene oxidation in industrial settings, H2O2 is often preferred as an oxidant because it is more environmental friendly. H2O2-based oxidation is usually chosen because the reaction generates only H2O as the primary by-product. Furthermore, H2O2 delivers a high content of active oxygen species (ca. 47wt.%) and is safer to use than other oxidants (e.g., TBHP, organic peroxides and peracids). As far as heterogeneous catalysis is concerned, a notable recent report includes the selective oxidation of toluene using a binary metal oxide as catalyst and H2O2 as oxidant [30]; however, the reaction gave only 57.5% conversion of toluene and 84.4% benzaldehyde as its maximum selectivity. Herein, we report a facile physical mixing synthetic method that produces Ti-containing silica materials and highly active and selective TS-1-like catalysts in high yield for direct oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. The synthesis of the catalysts involves simple physical mixing of commercially available precursors, namely TEOS and different titanium alkoxides, under ambient condition (Scheme 1 ). Furthermore, compared with methods such as solvothermal synthesis, which are often used to produce similar or related materials, the first part of the synthesis of the materials is carried out at room temperature, and is thus less energy intensive. Moreover, it yields highly catalytically active porous materials in high yield (ca. 98%) as compared with other methods. The materials show among the best catalytic performances for toluene oxidation, converting 98% toluene and affording ca. 100% benzaldehyde in 4h with H2O2 as oxidant. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and reagent Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), titanium(IV) isopropoxide, titanium(IV) n-butoxide, titanium(IV) bis(acetylacetonate)diisopropoxide, copper(II) chloride, hydrochloric acid (HCl) solution (36.5%), and poly(ethylene oxide)-block-poly(propylene oxide)-block-poly(ethylene oxide) (P123) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and they were all used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous titanium-silicate In the synthesis of the titanium silicate catalysts, 5.40g of TEOS, 1.43g of P123, 0.38g of different types of titania precursors (namely, titanium diisopropoxide bis(acetylacetonate), titanium(IV) isopropoxide and titanium(IV) n-butoxide), and 1.57mL of 0.01M HCl solution were physically mixed under ambient condition, until the corresponding sol-gel pastes were formed. The sol-gel pastes were then kept at room temperate overnight and subsequently calcined at 550°C for 5h in open atmosphere. This led to three different titanosilicate materials/catalysts, referred hereafter as TS-Bis, TS-Iso and TS-But, corresponding to titanium diisopropoxide bis(acetylacetonate), titanium(IV) isopropoxide and titanium n-butoxide precursors, respectively, which were used to make the materials from. Additionally, a copper-modified titanosilicate material was synthesized by including 0.15g of CuCl2 in the sol-gel precursor containing TEOS and titanium diisopropoxide bis(acetylacetonate). The copper titanium silicate material obtained from this synthesis was denoted as TS-Bis-Cu, in which the suffix “Cu” was included to indicate that the material was obtained from Cu2+-containing silica and titania precursors and that it had additionally some Cu species in it (vide infra). 2.3 Oxidation of toluene The catalytic performances of all the synthesized materials toward toluene oxidation reaction were studied in liquid phase using a two-neck round bottom flask. Into the flask, 0.2g catalyst, 3mL acetonitrile and 1.15mL (10.9mmol) toluene were mixed, and 3mL H2O2 (50% aq. solution) (52.7mmol) were added drop-wise at 80°C. H2O2 was added drop-wise in order to reduce its possible undesired decomposition, lower its ability to leach the catalyst and improve the catalytic yield of toluene oxidation as reported before [31,32]. The reaction mixture was stirred for 4h. At the end of the reaction, the catalyst was separated by filtration and the products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 6850) equipped with a HP-1 capillary column (30m length, 0.32mm id, 0.25μm film thickness) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The products were further identified using a GC–MS 5890 SERIES II instrument equipped with 5972 SERIES mass selective detector. After the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture via centrifugation, washed thoroughly with acetone and reused in multiple cycles. 3 Results and discussion Microstructural characterization of the titanosilicate and Cu-containing titanosilicate materials conducted by scanning electron microscopy equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) showed homogeneously distributed Ti, O, and Si atoms in all of the materials (Fig. 1 ). The result for TS-Bis-Cu additionally showed the presence of uniformly distributed Cu atoms in the material. The SEM images of all four materials, displayed in Fig. 2 a–d, showed micron-sized particles with some irregular morphologies and slight size variations. The TEM images (Fig. 2e–h) revealed that the particles possess mesoporous structures that appeared to have short diffusion pathways from the external surfaces. The observed porous structures with such short pore lengths could be expected to facilitate molecular diffusions of various guest molecules or reactants into the materials during catalysis. Wide-angle XRD studies indicated that the materials had amorphous frameworks (Fig. 3 a). However, the XRD pattern of TS-Bis-Cu showed some diffraction peaks at 2θ of 35.5 and 37.9° indicating the presence of CuO in this material (JCPDS no. 48–1548). These results are further corroborated by TEM images (see below). The acidity of the materials was probed by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments (Fig. 3b). The TPD profiles of all the materials showed peaks at ca. 100°C. The peak was intense particularly in the TPD profile of TS-But indicating the presence of relatively large density of weak acid sites in this material compared with the other three. The TPD profiles also showed an additional peak between ca. 350–500°C, indicating the presence of strong acid sites, especially in TS-But. This peak was much smaller in the TPD profiles of the other three materials (TS-Iso, TS-Bis, and TS-Bis-Cu), suggesting the presence of a small density of strong acid sites in these three materials. Compared with TS-Bis, TS-Bis-Cu could be seen to have a smaller density of weak acid sites, but a slightly larger density of strong acid sites; this suggested that the weak acid sites in TS-Bis-Cu may have been covered by Cu species and they may have limited the adsorption of NH3 on the acidic sites on this material. Overall the above results indicated that the intensity of the two TPD peaks, corresponding to strong and weak acid sites, varied depending on the types of precursors used. Conversely, the types of titanium(IV) alkoxide precursors used to make the materials dictated the types and the densities of acid sites forming within the Ti-containing silica materials reported herein. This may, in turn, have to do with how effectively the titania precursors interact with the silica precursor, and how well the Ti and Si atoms are condensed into TiOSi structures. The hydrolysis of these precursors and the plausible reaction mechanism leading to the titanium silicate materials is depicted in Scheme 1. Therein, three different titanium alkoxides with different alkoxy groups are used as precursors, each along with TEOS. Compared with many transition metals of many sol-gel precursors, the silicon atoms in silicon alkoxides often have smaller partial positive charges (e.g., +0.32 in TEOS) (cf. the partial positive charge of Ti in Ti(OEt)4 is +0.63). As a result, silicon alkoxides (e.g., Si(OEt)4) are generally less susceptible to nucleophilic attack, and thus hydrolyze and condense slower than many transition metal alkoxides. On the other hand, the corresponding titanium alkoxides (e.g., Ti(OEt)4) undergo faster nucleophilic substitution and hydrolysis/condensation reactions. Similarly, metal alkoxides possessing bulkier alkoxy ligands around their metal atoms have slower hydrolysis and condensation rates than those containing less bulky alkoxy groups [14]. So, due to its relatively slower hydrolysis rate, closely matching that of TEOS, titanium(IV) n-butoxide should be able to form a higher density of Ti–O–Si structures with TEOS than do the other titania precursors tried here. In other words, compared with the other titania precursors, titanium(IV) n-butoxide and TEOS have the ability to co-condense and form a high density of Ti–O–Si structures, or a Ti-containing silica material possessing a large density of both weak and strong acidic sites [14]. This may also be the reason why this material showed better catalytic activity for toluene oxidation than the other materials (vide infra). So, the hydrolysis rate of the titania precursors with respect to that of TEOS, or the ability of the precursors to form Ti–O–Si structures (Scheme 1 above), can affect the acidity as well as the catalytic activity of the Ti-containing silica materials synthesized by the physical mixing method here. The porosity of all the materials was analyzed by N2 porosimetry. The results showed type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms for all the materials, indicating the presence of mesoporosity (Fig. 4 a). The BJH pore size distributions of the materials (Fig. 4b) also revealed the presence of mesoporous structures and reasonably uniform pore sizes. Furthermore, all the materials had similar BJH pore size distributions and average pore diameters centred at ca. 3nm (Fig. 4b). It is worth adding that the shape of the adsorption/desorption isotherm of TS-Iso appeared slightly different from those of the TS-But, TS-Bis, and TS-Bis-Cu. More specifically, the former showed a hysteresis loop and a larger surface area than the other three materials. TS-Iso also had the highest surface area (∼617m2/g) and pore volume (0.40cm3/g). The other three materials had surface areas in the range of 534–575m2 g−1 (Table 1 ). However, this does not necessarily mean the former would be a better catalyst for alkane oxidation than the other three materials (as is found below), because alkane oxidation depends also on whether the material has a higher density of the desired TiOSi bonds. Furthermore, the average pore diameter of TS-Iso was ∼3.2nm (TS-Iso) and those of TS-But, TS-Bis, and TS-Bis-Cu were all in the range of 2.8–3.0nm, or slightly lower. TS-Iso had a pore volume of 0.40cm3/g whereas TS-But, TS-Bis, and TS-Bis-Cu all had pore volumes in the range of 0.30–0.25cm3/g. The relatively lower surface area and also pore volume found in TS-But, TS-Bis and TS-Bis-Cu compared with those of TS-Iso may, once again, have to do with the relatively slower hydrolysis rates of their titania precursors with respect to that of TEOS, or their better ability to interact well with silicate groups and form hybrid materials. On the other hand, titanium(IV) isopropoxide has a faster hydrolysis rate; thus, it may have less time to interact with the silicate species during hydrolysis. As a result, instead of forming extensive TiOSi networks and hybrid structures, titanium(IV) isopropoxide and TEOS would likely form a mixture of phase-segregated but individually well-organized mesoporous TiO2 and mesoporous SiO2 materials, each possessing high surface area and high pore volume. The ability of the synthesized Ti-containing silica and Cu- and Ti-containing silica materials to catalyze selective oxidation of toluene was then evaluated (Table 2 ). First, as a control experiment, a mixture containing toluene and H2O2 without any catalyst was run at 80°C for 4h. As expected, no significant oxidation of toluene was observed in this case. However, when the reaction mixture containing toluene and H2O2 was stirred at 80°C in the presence of the Ti- (and Cu-) containing silica catalysts, the reactant underwent direct catalytic oxidation. In the presence of TS-Iso, the reaction afforded ca. 62% conversion of toluene in 4h, with benzaldehyde being the major product (88%) and cresols being the minor products (12%). In the presence of TS-Bis, the reaction progressed less slowly, giving only 40% conversion in 4h, albeit with very good selectivity (nearly 100%) of benzaldehyde. Interestingly, when TS-But was employed as a catalyst, the conversion of toluene was a whopping 98% in 4h, with almost 100% selectivity to benzaldehyde product. To the best of our knowledge, this is the highest conversion and selectivity ever reported for direct oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde by catalysts (Table S1 in SI). This catalyst also showed both better activity and higher selectivity to benzaldehyde than many other catalysts reported in the literature for the same reaction under comparable conditions (see Table S1 in SI). The better catalytic performance exhibited by TS-But for the reaction compared with those of the other catalysts can be attributed to its high acidity, as seen in the trend of acidity of the catalysts by NH3-TPD, depicted in Fig. 3b. In other words, TS-But gave more reactant conversion and higher selectivity to benzaldehyde compared to the other three catalysts reported here, because it had a much larger density of both weak acid and strong acid sites than the other three materials and because the oxidation of toluene, especially to benzaldehyde, requires both strong and weak acids, as illustrated in Scheme 2 . Interestingly, having copper in these catalysts was found to reverse the selectivity of the reaction in favour of different types of cresol products, as opposed to benzaldehyde. For instance, while TS-Bis gave ca. 100% selectivity to benzaldehyde product, with almost no cresols during toluene oxidation, TS-Bis-Cu gave 57% cresols as the major products and only 43% benzaldehyde in the reaction under the same condition, despite the conversion in the latter (ca. 55%) was slightly higher than the former (ca. 40%). The fact that the Cu-functionalized TS-Bis (or TS-Bis-Cu) showed better conversion in toluene oxidation and much less selectivity to benzaldehyde than the corresponding unmodified material (i.e., TS-Bis) clearly suggested that the Cu in the titanosilicate material played some role in the reaction. As a matter of fact, the copper-free Ti-containing silica catalysts exhibited a common feature of favouring benzaldehyde as a major product during toluene oxidation. This may be due to the ability of the copper-free Ti-containing silica catalysts to readily activate the sp3 carbon sites of toluene. On the other hand, the copper-containing Ti-containing silica catalyst may have the ability to activate the sp2 ring carbon sites as much as, or more than, it can activate the sp3 carbon sites in toluene. It is worth adding that all the catalysts reported herein also showed good reusability while maintaining their activity as well as selectivity in the oxidation reaction (Table 2). 4 Conclusions A facile synthetic route that yields Ti-containing silica catalysts for toluene oxidation has been reported. The catalytic properties (activity and selectivity) of the materials have been found to depend on their acidic properties, which in turn have been related to the types of precursors used to make them. The catalysts showed high catalytic activities toward toluene oxidation with up to 98% conversion and ca. 100% selectivity toward benzaldehyde. Interestingly, including Cu into the materials has led to a reversal of the selectivity of the catalysts in favour of cresols as products as opposed to benzaldehyde. Future work will include studies to unravel the exact interplay among the compositions/metallic sites, catalytic activities and reaction mechanisms in such catalysts in alkane oxidations. The work reported here may encourage further investigation on the potential application of the reported facile physical-mixing synthetic method to make other Ti-containing and metal-containing mesoporous silica catalysts for alkane oxidation. coredata.dc:description: We report a novel, facile, physical mixing synthetic method that leads to titanium silicate and copper titanium silicate materials or highly effective solid acid catalysts for toluene oxidation reaction. The synthesis involves simple physical mixing of tetraethyl orthosilicate and various titanium alkoxide (and also copper(II) chloride), and then calcination of the products. The effects of the types of precursors on the catalytic activity of the resulting materials are investigated. Notably, titanium(IV) n-butoxide, whose hydrolysis rate is close to that of tetraethyl orthosilicate, yields a material that exhibits strong acidic properties and excellent catalytic activity for toluene oxidation with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as oxidant, giving 98% conversion of toluene and ca. 100% selectivity to benzaldehyde product. The work demonstrates not only simplicity in terms of synthesis of the materials but also unprecedented solid-acid catalytic activity for titanium silicate materials, the catalytic properties of which can be easily tailored by varying the types of precursors. It is also noteworthy that the materials give among the best catalytic performance (in terms of both conversion and product selectivity) under mild reaction conditions that has been reported for toluene oxidation with H2O2 as oxidant for heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of efficient and selective Ti-containing mesoporous silica catalysts for toluene oxidation
